content.text: I don’t know when exactly it happened, but in 11th grade my algorithm decided my personality should now be “futuristic.” Neon. Glitchy. Green code. Everything with that matrixy energy. I clicked one video about futuristic UI and then my feed became a parent that only buys one type of toy. Holograms, cyber dashboards, keyboard click sounds that make you feel smarter.

Then I found a video: “Hacker Interfaces That Look Too Cool To Be Real.” And I connected two simple ideas: futuristic equals hacker. Hackers equal futuristic. Very original, I know. I decided I wanted that vibe. Not the crime part. Just the aesthetic. The "I am smarter than your entire building" energy.

So what did I do? I downloaded a VM. And not just any VM. Kali Linux. The OS that looks like it could launch missiles, even though mostly it just sits there looking dramatic. I had zero clue what I was doing. Googling: “how to open folder in kali linux,” “what does sudo mean.” Still, booting it up felt elite. A secret system inside my system. Scans, tools I didn't understand, pretending to be a cyber ninja while actually opening and closing windows three times.

I realised hackers aren’t cool because of hoodies or green code. They’re cool because they have control. Real control. Over systems, tools, logic. I wanted that more than the hoodie. My hacking phase ended when the VM crashed repeatedly and I decided I liked watching tutorials more than learning commands. But the vibe stayed. Curiosity creates the feeling of being futuristic. Even now, when I see a slick UI, a part of me whispers: “That could’ve been you.” Then my laptop fans make airplane noises and I take the hint.
